articles.headline: Obama’s Plan: Allow Drilling in Atlantic, but Limit It in Arctic
articles.snippet: The Obama administration moved Tuesday to open up a vast stretch of East Coast waters to oil and gas drilling.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration moved Tuesday to open up a vast stretch of East Coast waters to oil and gas drilling.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration moved Tuesday to open up a vast stretch of East Coast waters to oil and gas drilling, a decision that could have a profound impact on the economic and environmental future of states from Virginia to Georgia. The move also adds a new dimension to the legacy of President Obama.

articles.headline: Yahoo to Spin Off Its Stake in Alibaba
articles.snippet: Shedding its 15 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce site turns the spotlight to Yahoo’s plans to revamp its core Internet advertising business.
articles.abstract: Shedding its 15 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce site turns the spotlight to Yahoo’s plans to revamp its core Internet advertising business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer, chief executive of Yahoo, said on Tuesday that the Internet company would spin off its 15.4 percent stake in Alibaba, China’s leading e-commerce company, into a separate company.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: IPhone Sales in China Bolster Apple Earnings
articles.snippet: The introduction of a large-screen iPhone in China helped propel Apple’s profit to $18 billion and its revenue to nearly $75 billion.
articles.abstract: The introduction of a large-screen iPhone in China helped propel Apple’s profit to $18 billion and its revenue to nearly $75 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is famous for setting trends.

articles.headline: Obama Relents on Proposal to End ‘529’ College Savings Plans
articles.snippet: The president, facing pressure from both parties, dropped from his budget a proposal to effectively end college savings accounts known as 529s.
articles.abstract: The president, facing pressure from both parties, dropped from his budget a proposal to effectively end college savings accounts known as 529s.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, facing angry reprisals from parents and from lawmakers of both parties, will drop his proposal to effectively end the popular college savings accounts known as 529s, but will keep an expanded tuition tax credit at the center of his college access plan, White House officials said Tuesday.

articles.headline: Job Licenses in Spotlight as Uber Rises
articles.snippet: Regulations for many occupations create bottlenecks in the economy, raise the prices of goods and services and put good jobs out of reach of many Americans.
articles.abstract: Regulations for many occupations create bottlenecks in the economy, raise the prices of goods and services and put good jobs out of reach of many Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: What lesson should we draw from the success of Uber?

articles.headline: U.S. Strengths Buoy Consumers but Hurt Corporations With Business Abroad
articles.snippet: A growing number of big American multinational companies have begun to suffer from lower oil prices and a strong dollar.
articles.abstract: A growing number of big American multinational companies have begun to suffer from lower oil prices and a strong dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is good for the American consumer may be less so for big American companies.

articles.headline: Russian Movie ‘Leviathan’ Gets Applause in Hollywood but Scorn at Home
articles.snippet: The film has admirers and won a Golden Globe, but some Russian detractors want it banned and accuse its director of acting under Western orders.
articles.abstract: The film has admirers and won a Golden Globe, but some Russian detractors want it banned and accuse its director of acting under Western orders.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In many ways, the movie “Leviathan” is Russia’s greatest cinematic accomplishment in years, maybe decades. The Golden Globe winner this month for best foreign film, it provides an unrelenting, vodka-soaked portrait of small-town corruption that has been praised by critics and filmmakers throughout the world — everywhere, it seems, but Russia.

articles.headline: ‘Empire’ May Provide Fox the Big Hit It Needs
articles.snippet: Ratings for the hip-hop drama lead the network and have increased steadily since the show’s introduction, lifting Fox out of last place in the network ratings war.
articles.abstract: Ratings for the hip-hop drama lead the network and have increased steadily since the show’s introduction, lifting Fox out of last place in the network ratings war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox’s new hip-hop drama “Empire” is proving to be a platinum property for a network that desperately needed one.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Ben Sisario

articles.headline: Hezbollah Kills 2 Israeli Soldiers Near Lebanon
articles.snippet: The missile strike was the latest in a string of events along Israel’s northern frontiers that have raised the risk of a broader confrontation.
articles.abstract: The missile strike was the latest in a string of events along Israel’s northern frontiers that have raised the risk of a broader confrontation.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Hezbollah antitank missiles killed two Israeli soldiers as they drove in a disputed area along the Lebanese border on Wednesday, a sharp retaliation for Israel’s deadly drone strike last week that killed six Hezbollah fighters and an Iranian general.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: New Rules in China Upset Western Tech Companies
articles.snippet: Stringent regulations, including a requirement to share secret codes, are another form of economic protectionism, Western technology companies say.
articles.abstract: Stringent regulations, including a requirement to share secret codes, are another form of economic protectionism, Western technology companies say.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government has adopted new regulations requiring companies that sell computer equipment to Chinese banks to turn over secret source code, submit to invasive audits and build so-called back doors into hardware and software, according to a copy of the rules obtained by foreign technology companies that do billions of dollars’ worth of business in China.

articles.headline: Charles H. Townes, Who Paved Way for the Laser in Daily Life, Dies at 99
articles.snippet: Dr. Townes shared the Nobel Prize in 1964 for his work on lasers, in a career that included advising on lunar landings, verifying Einstein’s theories and creating an atomic clock.
articles.abstract: Dr. Townes shared the Nobel Prize in 1964 for his work on lasers, in a career that included advising on lunar landings, verifying Einstein’s theories and creating an atomic clock.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charles H. Townes, a visionary physicist whose research led to the development of the laser, making it possible to play CDs, scan prices at the supermarket, measure time precisely, survey planets and galaxies, and even witness the birth of stars, died on Tuesday in Oakland, Calif. He was 99.
